<QuestionSource url="https://www.cdc.gov/measles/data-research/index.html">
# Summary of CDC Measles Cases and Outbreaks Article

**Date of Article:** February 06, 2026 (data as of February 5, 2026)

## Key Statistics for 2026 (as of February 5, 2026):

- **Total confirmed measles cases in 2026:** 733 cases
  - 727 cases reported by 20 U.S. jurisdictions: Arizona, California, Florida, Georgia, Idaho, Kentucky, Minnesota, Nebraska, North Carolina, North Dakota, Ohio, Oklahoma, Oregon, Pennsylvania, South Carolina, South Dakota, Utah, Virginia, Washington, and Wisconsin
  - 6 cases among international visitors to the U.S.

- **Outbreaks in 2026:** 2 new outbreaks reported
- **Outbreak-associated cases:** 92% (671 of 733 cases)
  - 9 cases from outbreaks starting in 2026
  - 662 cases from outbreaks that started in 2025

## Historical Context - 2025 Data:

- **Total confirmed measles cases in 2025:** 2,276 cases
  - 2,251 cases reported by 45 jurisdictions
  - 25 cases among international visitors
- **Outbreaks in 2025:** 49 outbreaks
- **Outbreak-associated cases in 2025:** 89% (2,029 of 2,276 cases)

## Historical Context - 2024 Data:

- **Total confirmed measles cases in 2024:** 285 cases
  - 269 cases from 32 jurisdictions
  - 16 cases among international visitors
- **Outbreaks in 2024:** 16 outbreaks
- **Outbreak-associated cases in 2024:** 69% (198 of 285 cases)
- **Hospitalization rate in 2024:** 40% (114 of 285 cases)

## Additional Historical Data:
- 2023: 59 cases, 4 outbreaks
- 2022: 121 cases
- 2021: 49 cases
- 2020: 13 cases
- 2019: 1,274 cases

## Vaccination Coverage:

- MMR vaccine effectiveness: 2 doses are 97% effective, 1 dose is 93% effective
- Vaccination coverage among U.S. kindergartners has **decreased from 95.2% (2019-2020 school year) to 92.5% (2024-2025 school year)**
- This leaves approximately **286,000 kindergartners at risk** during the 2024-2025 school year
- Community immunity requires >95% vaccination coverage

## Important Notes:

- Case counts for 2025-2026 are **preliminary and subject to change**
- CDC updates reflect only **confirmed measles cases** notified to CDC as of noon on Thursdays
- Breakthrough infections (infections in vaccinated individuals) occur in approximately 10% of all measles infections
- Measles was officially eliminated from the U.S. in 2000 (no domestic transmission)
</QuestionSource>
